title: "Exercises for Brain Hemisphere Development"
first_phrase: In the previous text, we talked about how breathing affects our popularity, as well as exercises such as "alternate nostril breathing" and "near-far point focus" to balance the activation of both brain hemispheres. Now, we'll dive deeper into these exercises and explore additional ones. Ernest Rossi's research on "alternate nostril breathing" showed how our breathing alternates between nostrils and corresponds to the different activities of our brain hemispheres. The "near-far point focus" exercise involves focusing on a distant point and maintaining peripheral awareness of a nearby point. The addition of holding the breath while maintaining focus adds another level of difficulty. Finally, we'll talk about an additional exercise, the "third eye focus," which comes from Eastern practices and helps balance and develop both hemispheres.
content: Este ejercicio, cuando es correctamente seguido, reúne en si dos elementos: 1) Ajuste de la mirada 2) El hecho de que ambos ojos estén “despiertos" Esercizio 83 – Cercano - Lejano Teniendo la mano tiesa en frente a si, prácticamente consiste en el fijar primero el proprio pulgar y luego a distancia. Si el ejercicio es realizado bien, veremos, en el campo lateral, como dos pulgares (datos de la visión no centrada de los ojos9 cuando miramos distante y como dos objetos distantes (datos siempre de la visión no centrada de los ojos) cuando miramos cerca. La observación del tercer ojo como adicionales ejercicios para el desarrollo de los hemisferios Mencionamos un ejercicio adicional, que forma parte de la disciplina oriental del “tratak” y también es practicado sobre la presencia[224] que igualmente desarrolla entre ambos hemisferios y que por lo tanto ayuda al desarrollo de la fascinación: la así llamada fijación del tercer ojo o “ojo de shiva”.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the practice of exercises like Esercizio 83 and 84 that involve adjusting the gaze and opening up both eyes can help in the development of the hemispheres of the brain. Additionally, focusing on the third eye or "ojo de shiva" can lead to a broader perception of reality and activation between both hemispheres, contributing to a more detailed coordination. Practicing these exercises regularly can lead to significant improvements in visual and mental performance.
